reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Multi-sectoral Emergency Response to Vulnerable Communities

description.narrative: This proposal includes two interventions which will aim to respond to the most acute humanitarian needs among Palestine refugees and non-refugees in the West Bank. The two project components presented seek to mitigate the needs among some of the most vulnerable communities facing access restrictions to health services and food insecurity in the West Bank, including Bedouin and herder communities in the Central West Bank at risk of forcible transfer due to the ongoing pressure to relocate them to Israeli designated sites. The two interventions aim to provide immediate relief through in-kind food support and primary health care services, to approximately 140,000 Palestinian refugees and non-refugees. The Mobile Health Clinics will deploy six teams to provide primary health care services to 39 communities within mainly Area C. The Bedouin and Herder food distribution programme is operated jointly with WFP, of which UNRWA supports with logistics and personnel for food distribution, while WFP procures food items. The food items are distributed to communities assessed as food insecure and vulnerable to protection concerns, including settlement violence and risk of forcible transfer. The overall project will be implemented and support all households in the targeted localities and will ensure that female headed households and other vulnerable individuals are supported to access the assistance provided in their communities. This project is deemed essential to meet the most urgent health and food needs of vulnerable communities within West Bank, including East Jerusalem. Since UNRWA is one of the largest service provider in the West Bank within these two sectors, an abrupt reduction in services would create a critical gap in terms of meeting humanitarian needs in Palestine.
